Award.AwardTitle: Technician Training in CRISPR-based Gene Editing
Award.AbstractNarration:
CRISPR-based gene editing is revolutionizing biological research as a mechanism to efficiently and precisely modify the genome of almost any organism. As a result of the wide incorporation of CRISPER-based technologies in genetic engineering, there is a need for a biotechnology workforce that is trained in its use. Community colleges are adept at meeting rapidly changing workforce needs such as this. To this end, Delaware Technical Community College proposes to develop and incorporate CRISPR-based gene editing training into its biotechnology curriculum. This work will be done in collaboration with the Gene Editing Institute at ChristianaCare, a Delaware-based healthcare organization. The project also aims to provide workshops to train community college faculty across the nation in CRISPR-based gene editing techniques. The trained faculty can in turn educate large numbers of students about this gene editing technique, to better prepare students for the current biotechnology workforce.

This partnership combines the content expertise of staff at the Gene Editing Institute with that of faculty at Delaware Technical Community College to develop and implement a high impact CRISPR-based gene editing curriculum and to offer training workshops for faculty. The project includes engagement with industry partners and national experts in bioethics. The professional development workshops will enable participants to broaden biotechnology instruction related to CRISPR use, as well related ethical issues. Through these activities, the project expects to serve nearly 100 bioscience students at Delaware Technical Community College and 90 community college faculty. The intention is to help students gain the knowledge and skills needed to contribute to a rapidly expanding field with a wide range of applications. The specific aims of the project are to: (1) continue to update and provide effective training in state-of-the-art gene editing techniques to prepare students in a two-year biotechnology program to enter bioscience careers or further education; (2) disseminate an advanced, current curriculum and model high impact teaching practices to community college instructors through three and five day gene editing workshops. The employability skills of graduates will be strengthened and broadened with the use of classroom activities that involve analysis and interpretation of bioinformatic data, technical oral presentations, understanding and evaluation of scientific literature, and group work as examples. As a result of these efforts, the project team expects to contribute to the national need for technicians who are skilled in gene editing technologies. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Delaware Technical & Community College Stanton-Newark Campus

Performance_Institution.Name: Delaware Technical & Community College Stanton-Newark Campus

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Technician Training in CRISPR Gene Editing project bridges the gap in the rate of development and training of community college students to meet industry needs in the rapidly evolving field of targeted gene editing.  Cutting edge techniques and information developed by researchers at the Gene Editing Institute (GEI), ChristianaCare Health System, and implemented as life science training curricula by faculty and students at Delaware Technical Community College (DTCC). 

Gene editing lab curriculum utilizing mammalian cell tissue culture, yeast, and an in vitro based reaction were incorporated into capstone Genetics and Molecular Biology courses at DTCC.  These training activities were expanded with learning of related bioinformatics training and targeted emphasis on the bioethics of a rapidly developing field.  This has resulted in hundreds of DTCC students receiving hands-on training in gene editing.  Several graduates of the program are applying their training while employed in laboratories using CRISPR gene editing. Other program graduates have been hired as a technicians utilizing cell culture techniques applying skills learned utilizing equipment acquired through project funding.

A series of professional development workshops targeting community college faculty were developed and run virtually to facilitate dissemination of gene editing curriculum nationally.  More than two dozen faculty from community colleges attended to learn about advances in CRISPR gene editing from GEI scientists and related curricula implementation at the community college level.  As a result of the virtual workshops, commercial availability of a gene editing laboratory kit, CRISPR gene editing information and lab activities have been implemented and enhanced in community college programs across the country. 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: John Mcdowell

  • DTCC students are shown in a tissue culture lab. They are performing a CRISPR gene editing experiment to correct a GFP mutation in mammalian cells.

    DTCC Students Performing CRISPR on Cultured Cells
  • Results of CRISPR procedure performed by DTCC students. CRISPR was used to correct a mutation in GFP. Cells which contain properly edited DNA are shown as fluorescing under UV illumination.
    John McDowell
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    John Mcdowell
    GFP Fluorescence in CRISPR Edited Cells
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Technician Training in CRISPR Gene Editing project bridges the gap in the rate of development and training of community college students to meet industry needs in the rapidly evolving field of targeted gene editing. Cutting edge techniques and information developed by researchers at the Gene Editing Institute (GEI), ChristianaCare Health System, and implemented as life science training curricula by faculty and students at Delaware Technical Community College (DTCC). Gene editing lab curriculum utilizing mammalian cell tissue culture, yeast, and an in vitro based reaction were incorporated into capstone Genetics and Molecular Biology courses at DTCC. These training activities were expanded with learning of related bioinformatics training and targeted emphasis on the bioethics of a rapidly developing field. This has resulted in hundreds of DTCC students receiving hands-on training in gene editing. Several graduates of the program are applying their training while employed in laboratories using CRISPR gene editing. Other program graduates have been hired as a technicians utilizing cell culture techniques applying skills learned utilizing equipment acquired through project funding. A series of professional development workshops targeting community college faculty were developed and run virtually to facilitate dissemination of gene editing curriculum nationally. More than two dozen faculty from community colleges attended to learn about advances in CRISPR gene editing from GEI scientists and related curricula implementation at the community college level. As a result of the virtual workshops, commercial availability of a gene editing laboratory kit, CRISPR gene editing information and lab activities have been implemented and enhanced in community college programs across the country.
